Comment: To avoid the Ruy Lopez, which she always seemed to win quickly with against me. This time it didn't help.

I try to develop my pieces quickly.
I did not want to see her play P-Q5 and blow apart my position.
I did not want to see her play P-Q5 and blow apart my position.
I was actually glad she didn't reply QxP. Any time her Queen came out, I knew I was in for it.
If I play N-QB3, I was worried she'd exchange and rip open my Q-side.
Uh-oh. She saw something I missed, as usual. [sigh]
Oh, boy. If I play Q-K1, my K and Q are in the perfect positions to be forked at some point by one of her Knights. So...
I hate having my King exposed, but I'm hoping against hope I can find a way to stop the King-hunt.

A beautiful epaulette mate, although at the time I didn't know that term.  Yet another quick loss to the school's chess queen. Well, at least it makes for a nice posting 20 years later, as it's a gorgeous attack.
